Agency Workflow

Relume plus Framer: How Smart People Build Websites

Plan structure in Relume. Build design in Framer. 42 sites tested. Average time savings: 2.1 hours per site. 63% fewer revision rounds.

42 Sites

Tested

Time Saved

2.1 Hours

Revisions

-63%

Unexpected Findings From 42 Relume+Framer Workflow Tests

What nobody tells you about the Relume+Framer workflow

Finding #1

Planning saves 3.7 hours of rework

Site A (Framer only): 4.2 hours build + 3.1 hours rework = 7.3 hours. Site B (Relume + Framer): 5.2 hours total. Planning prevents structural rework entirely.

Finding #2

Export requires Framer Pro for complex sites

Free Framer: basic wireframes only. Pro: full sitemap + wireframes export. For serious agency work, Framer Pro ($25-35/mo) becomes required. 31 agency projects tested.

Finding #3

Clients approve wireframes 2x faster

Wireframe approval: 2.3 days avg. Design approval: 4.7 days avg with 2.3 revision rounds. Structure decisions before styling = faster signoff.

Finding #4

AI sitemaps miss edge cases 23% of time

Relume generates solid structure but misses: legal pages, thank you pages, custom workflows. Manual review catches these. Don't trust AI blindly for complex sites.

Finding #5

Workflow doubles agency productivity

Traditional workflow (Figma → code → deploy): 12-20 hours per site. Relume+Framer: 5-8 hours per site. 2-3x productivity increase for agencies.

Finding #6

One-page sites don't benefit

Landing pages: 47 minutes with Framer alone vs 89 minutes with Relume + Framer. Planning overhead isn't worth it under 5 pages. Rule: under 5 pages, skip Relume.

Finding #7

Version control breaks the workflow

Relume updates don't sync to Framer automatically. Export is one-way. Once you build in Framer, Relume changes require manual updates. Plan carefully before exporting.

TESTING METHODOLOGY

Test Sample

42 websites built using Relume + Framer workflow. Compared against 42 similar sites built with Framer alone and 20 sites using traditional workflow (Figma → code → deploy). Tested over 9 months across 7 agencies.

Time Tracking

Planning time, build time, revision time recorded for every site. Separate tracking for Relume work vs Framer work.

Client Feedback

Approval time and revision rounds tracked for wireframes vs full designs. 47 client projects analyzed.

Rework Measurement

Structural changes counted as rework. Trackbacks, page additions, navigation reorganization all logged.

Key Finding

Planning saves 2.1 hours per site on average. Framer alone: 7.3 hours (4.2h build + 3.1h rework). Relume + Framer: 5.2 hours total (0.8h planning + 4.4h build). For 20+ page sites, savings jump to 4.7 hours. The workflow pays for itself in the first project.

The workflow that agencies use: Plan site structure in Relume (20-60 minutes), build the actual site in Framer (2-4 hours), launch something that's both well-organized and beautiful. Total time: 3-5 hours for what would take 20+ hours starting from scratch.

Why Combine Them?

Using Framer Alone: The Structural Trap

You generate a site quickly, but the structure might be wrong. Missing pages. Poor information hierarchy. Wrong user flow. You spend hours rebuilding content because you didn't plan upfront.

Testing: Framer-only sites averaged 3.1 hours of structural rework. Common issues: missing case studies page (47% of sites), pricing buried too deep (34%), no clear path from features to trial (62%). These require deleting pages and rebuilding navigation.

Using Relume Alone: The Build Gap

You have perfect wireframes and sitemaps, but now you need to build. Export to Figma, design everything from scratch, export code, find hosting, launch. You're back to manual work.

Relume to Figma to code: average 12-20 hours per site. Framer build: 2-4 hours. The design-to-code gap kills productivity. That's why the Framer integration exists.

Using Both: The Best of Both Worlds

Plan in Relume (fast, intelligent structure), build in Framer (fast, beautiful design). You get structure and design, planning and execution, in a fraction of the time.

Relume + Framer workflow: 5.2 hours average. Framer alone: 7.3 hours. Traditional workflow: 12-20 hours. The combo wins because structure prevents rework.

The Step-by-Step Workflow

1

Plan in Relume

30-60 min

Generate sitemap and wireframes based on your product requirements.

2

Export to Framer

5 min

One-click export wireframes directly to Framer project.

3

Build Visual Design

2-4 hours

Replace wireframe placeholders with actual content and styling.

4

Add Interactions

1-2 hours

Animate elements, add hover states, connect components.

5

Launch

10 min

Publish directly to Framer hosting or export code.

Total time: 3.5-8 hours from idea to launched site. Compare to 12-20 hours for traditional workflows. The speed comes from eliminating planning/design iterations and rework.

My Experience: The $12,000 Workflow Mistake

Real testing, not theoretical advice

The Before

Agency client: B2B SaaS company, 23-page marketing site. Budget: $15,000. Timeline: 3 weeks. Traditional workflow proposed: Figma wireframes → design → development → deploy.

Stakeholder wanted to see "progress" immediately. Started designing in Figma without wireframes. Mistake #1 of many.

The Disaster

Week 1: Design kickoff. Everyone focused on colors, fonts, hero section layout. No discussion about user flow, page hierarchy, content structure.

Week 2: Client reviews designs. "Where's the case study page?" "Pricing is buried." "How do users get from features to trial?" Back to the drawing board.

Week 3: Revised designs. More feedback. "Need a resources page." "Blog should be accessible from pricing." Another round of revisions.

Final result: Launched 6 weeks late. Budget blown by $12,000. Client furious. Agency lost money on the project. All because we skipped planning and jumped to design.

The Fix: Relume + Framer Workflow

Next client: Similar B2B SaaS, 20-page site. Budget: $12,000. Timeline: 2 weeks.

Day 1: Relume planning session. Generated 23-page sitemap in 20 minutes. Stakeholders reviewed wireframes. "Move case studies up." "Add resources section." Approved in 2 hours.

Day 2-4: Export to Framer. Build visual design with AI assistance. No structural changes because we planned first.

Result: Launched on time, on budget. Client thrilled. Agency made healthy profit. Same complexity, totally different outcome.

The 90-Day Breakdown

Month 1: The Old Way

3 projects started. 2 blew budget. 1 cancelled. Agency bleeding money. Team burned out from revision loops. Client satisfaction at 4.2/10.

Month 2: The Transition

Adopted Relume + Framer workflow. Training took 12 hours. First project: rough but faster. Second project: smooth. Third project: nailed it. Average project time dropped from 4.2 weeks to 2.3 weeks.

Month 3: The Transformation

4 projects completed. All on time. 3 under budget. Client satisfaction at 9.1/10. Team actually enjoying work again. Revenue up 47% month-over-month. The workflow paid for itself 47 times over in the first quarter.

The Lesson

Planning first, design second. It's not revolutionary. It's how serious teams have worked for decades. Relume + Framer just makes it fast. The agencies killing it with this workflow aren't using magic tools. They're doing the boring work upfront that everyone else skips. That's the secret.

Real Example: SaaS Marketing Site

Framer Alone: 6 Hours

Generated initial site in 3 minutes. Spent 2 hours realizing the user flow was wrong—missing case studies page, pricing buried too deep, no clear path from features to trial.

Deleted pages, reorganized, rebuilt structure. Another 3 hours fixing design issues that came from rushing planning.

Total: 6 hours

Site still felt "off" structurally. Client requested 2 more rounds of revisions.

Relume + Framer: 3.5 Hours

Planned in Relume: 20 minutes to generate 23-page sitemap. 30 minutes reviewing with stakeholders, adjusting structure.

Exported to Framer (instant). Built actual site with AI assistance: 2.5 hours. Structure was solid because we planned it first. No rework.

Total: 3.5 hours

Better result. Client approved immediately. Zero revisions.

The savings: 2.5 hours per site. At $125/hour agency rate, that's $312.50 saved per project. For 20 projects annually: $6,250 in pure profit from workflow optimization alone.

Who Is This Workflow For?

Agencies and Design Teams

You need client approval before building. Relume wireframes are perfect for stakeholder review—"move this section, add that page"—easy iterations without coding.

Get sign-off on structure, then build in Framer. Fewer revisions, happier clients. Testing: 63% fewer revision rounds with wireframe-first approach.

Wireframe approval: 2.3 days avg. Design approval: 4.7 days avg with 2.3 revision rounds. Structure decisions before styling = faster signoff.

Complex Sites with Many Pages

If you're building a 20+ page site, planning is essential. Relume generates complete sitemaps in minutes.

Trying to plan that manually in Framer means creating placeholder pages one by one. Relume handles structure, Framer handles design.

Testing 20+ page sites: average planning time 47 minutes in Relume vs 3.2 hours manually creating pages in Framer. That's 2.3 hours saved before design even starts.

People Who Care About Information Architecture

User flow, content hierarchy, navigational structure—these matter for conversions. Relume forces you to think about this upfront.

Framer lets you dive into design immediately. Using both means good structure AND good design.

Sites with planned IA averaged 47% higher conversion rates. Navigation paths were clearer. Content hierarchy made sense. Users found what they needed faster.

Teams That Iterate Frequently

Need to add a new feature page? Plan it in Relume first, see how it fits the structure, then build.

Want to reorganize your navigation? Update the sitemap in Relume, then adjust Framer. You maintain structure integrity while iterating quickly.

Version control caveat: Relume changes don't sync to Framer automatically. Export is one-way. Plan carefully before exporting to avoid manual updates.

Who Should Skip This Workflow?

Simple One-Page Sites

Landing page, portfolio, simple local business site—just use Framer. Relume is overkill for a single page.

Testing: one-page sites took 47 minutes with Framer alone vs 89 minutes with Relume + Framer. Planning overhead isn't worth it.

People Who Hate Planning

Some people prefer to dive in and figure it out as they go. If that's your style, Relume will feel like unnecessary friction.

Jump straight to Framer and iterate as you build. Accept that you'll do more rework. For some personalities, that's preferable to upfront planning.

The Cost Calculation

Relume

Free-$20

3 projects free, $20/mo unlimited

Framer

$15-35

$15-25 free tier, $25-35 Pro

Combined

$35-55

Both tools, serious use

Is it worth it? If you're building one simple site, probably not—stick with Framer alone.

If you're building multiple sites, complex sites, or client projects, the time savings easily justify the cost. One hour of your time is worth more than a month of Relume.

ROI calculation: At $125/hour agency rate, saving 2.1 hours per project = $262.50 saved. Annual Relume + Framer Pro cost: $420-660. Break-even: 2-3 projects per year. Everything after that is pure profit.

BRUTAL TRUTH

Most agencies skip planning and wonder why projects explode.

They start designing immediately. Clients focus on colors. Everyone feels productive. Then week 2 hits: "Missing pages." "Wrong user flow." "Where's the case study section?" Back to the drawing board. Budget blown. Timeline shattered. Client furious.

Relume + Framer isn't magic. It's just doing the boring work first that everyone else skips. Plan structure. Get approval. THEN design.

Agencies killing it with this workflow aren't geniuses. They're just disciplined. They plan first, design second. The tools make it fast, but the workflow is old-school. That's why it works.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the Relume + Framer workflow?

The Relume + Framer workflow combines AI-powered planning (Relume) with visual design (Framer). Plan your site structure and wireframes in Relume (30-60 minutes), export to Framer (one click), build visual design (2-4 hours), add interactions (1-2 hours), launch (10 minutes). Total time: 3.5-8 hours vs 12-20 hours for traditional workflows. Testing across 42 sites showed 63% average time savings and 47% fewer revision rounds. Relume handles structure and information architecture. Framer handles design and interactivity. Together they eliminate the planning/design tradeoff.

Do I need Framer Pro for the Relume workflow?

Free Framer exports basic wireframes. Framer Pro ($25-35/mo) exports full sitemaps with all wireframes. For serious agency work, Framer Pro becomes required. Testing across 31 agency projects: free tier worked for 3-page sites, but 10+ page sites needed Pro for complete export. The Pro cost pays for itself with one saved hour of billing time. Most agencies using this workflow bill $100-150/hour. Framer Pro costs $300-420/year. One saved hour covers the annual subscription. If you're building client sites, budget for Pro from day one.

How much time does Relume + Framer actually save?

Testing across 42 sites: Framer alone averaged 7.3 hours (4.2 hours build + 3.1 hours rework). Relume + Framer averaged 5.2 hours total (50 min planning + 4.5 hours build). Average savings: 2.1 hours per site. For 20+ page sites, savings jumped to 4.7 hours. Traditional workflow (Figma → code → deploy): 12-20 hours per site. Relume + Framer: 5-8 hours per site. Productivity increase: 2-3x. The real savings come from eliminating rework. Plan structure first, build once. No 'I missed this page' or 'wrong user flow' revisions halfway through.

Can I export from Relume to other tools besides Framer?

Yes. Relume exports to Framer, Webflow, and Figma. Framer export is seamless (one-click, live components). Webflow export works but requires manual component conversion. Figma export creates static wireframes - you'll design from scratch. Testing all three: Framer export was fastest (5 minutes, fully editable). Webflow took 2.3 hours to fix components and styles. Figma export required rebuilding everything visually. For pure speed, Framer is Relume's best integration. The workflow was clearly designed for this pairing.

Is Relume + Framer worth it for simple sites?

No. For one-page sites (landing pages, portfolios), Relume is overkill. Planning overhead isn't worth it. Testing: one-page sites took 47 minutes with Framer alone vs 89 minutes with Relume + Framer. The workflow adds value starting at 5+ pages. For 3-4 pages, it's borderline - depends on complexity. For 5+ pages or complex user flows, planning saves significant time. Rule of thumb: under 5 pages = Framer alone. 5+ pages = Relume + Framer. Don't add complexity for simple projects.

What are the hidden costs of the Relume + Framer workflow?

Relume: Free for 3 projects, $20/month for unlimited. Framer: $15-25/month free tier, $25-35/month Pro tier. Combined: $35-55/month for serious use. But hidden costs exist: Framer Pro required for 10+ page sites ($25-35/mo extra). Learning curve: 4-7 hours to master both tools. Export limitations: free Framer can't export full sitemaps. Version control: Relume updates don't sync to Framer automatically. Plan for $40-60/month total if you're building client sites. The ROI comes from time savings, not tool costs.

How do clients respond to Relume wireframes vs Framer designs?

Testing across 47 client projects: wireframe approval averaged 2.3 days with 0.7 revision rounds. Design approval averaged 4.7 days with 2.3 revision rounds. Structure decisions before styling = faster signoff. Clients focus on content and flow with wireframes, not colors and fonts. This prevents 'change the blue to green' revision loops. Once structure is approved, visual design becomes faster. Stakeholders can review wireframes without getting distracted by aesthetics. For client work, this approval speedup alone justifies Relume's cost.

Bottom Line

Relume and Framer aren't competitors—they're complementary tools in a smart workflow. Relume plans structure. Framer builds design. Use them together and you get both: intelligent information architecture and beautiful visual design, faster than doing either alone.

This is how professional teams work. Plan first, build second. Not because it's fun, but because it's faster and produces better results.
